title-group.article-title: The Taxation of Husband and Wife: Equity, Efficiency and Female Labour Supply

p.mixed-citation: To some extent questions of privacy become less important when the principle of symmetrical treatment of men and women is adopted, since each is subject to the same rules.

However, as with trade between countries, strategic considerations in the face of uncertain future relations place a limit on the optimal degree of specialisation.

It is not clear to me that there are significant economies of scale; rather, I would prefer to think of any financial savings from communal living being balanced by the disadvantages of sharing kitchens and bathrooms!

Whilst I do not propose to address this problem at length, it seems worthwhile pointing out that for efficiency and equity it would be necessary to move to a tax base that represented the earnings and/or domestic production potential rather than the actual earnings of the individual.

A parallel argument can be made to justify tax-deductibility of all payments to persons hired to work in the home, e.g. domestic cleaners. Also allowing tax deductibility of such payments removes the element of double taxation in the present system. Under independent taxation with full transferability and full deductibility, the event of a man marrying his housekeeper would not cause any change in the tax base. If such expenses were deductible, the rule would have to apply to all individuals, whether single or married.
Disabled adults should, as now, receive their own dependant allowance which can be used to pay those looking after them.
